data.title: Famous Birthdays on May 20
data.meta_description: Famous birthdays for the 20th of May. See which celebrities, historical figures, scientists and criminals were born on May 20.
data.text:
Birthdays 1 - 200 of 271

Bonne of Luxembourg, wife of John II of France (d. 1349)

Henry Percy [Harry Hotspur], English knight, soldier and politician (d. 1403)

Pietro Bembo, Italian writer, literary theorist, and Catholic cardinal, born in Venice, Venice Republic (d. 1547)

Hieronymus Fabricius Ab Aquapende Italian physician (De Formato Foetu), born in Aquapende, Italy (d. 1619)

Melchior Bischoff, German composer, born in Pößneck, Electorate of Saxony (d. 1614)

Paolo Bellasio, Italian composer, born in Verona, Republic of Venice (d. 1594)

Jacob Jordaens, Flemish baroque artist (after Rubens and Anthony van Dyck the leading Flemish painter), born in Antwerp (d. 1678)

1593 Salomo Glassius, German theologian (d. 1656)

Andreas Schlüter, German sculptor (d. 1714)

William Bradford, English-born colonial printer (Pennsylvania's first printing press), born in Leicestershire, England (d. 1752)

Seth Pomeroy, American gunsmith and soldier (d. 1777)

Roger Newdigate, British politician (sat in the House of Commons 1742-80), born in Arbury, Warwickshire (d. 1806)

Francis Cotes, English painter (d. 1770)

Toussaint Louverture

Haitian general, revolutionary and most famous of the leaders of the Haitian Revolution, born in Cap-Français, French colony of Saint-Domingue

Stephen Girard, French-born American banker (bailed out US bonds during War of 1812), born in Bordeaux, France (d. 1831)

Hans Gram, Danish-American organist, composer, and musicologist, born in Copenhagen, Denmark (d. 1804)

William Thornton, British-American architect (Capitol Building in Washington, D.C), born in Jost Van Dyke, British Virgin Islands (d. 1828)

Johann Gottfried Schadow, German sculptor (Brandenburg Gate chariot), born in Berlin, Prussia (d. 1850)

Dolley Madison, American 4th First Lady of the United States (1809-17) as wife of President James Madison, born in Guildford County, North Carolina (d. 1849) [1]

Andreas Vokos Miaoulis, Greek admiral and politician (d. 1835)

William Congreve, English artillery officer and inventor who designed fire rockets, born in London (d. 1829)

Simon Fraser, Canadian explorer and fur trader (explored the Fraser River), born in Mapletown, New York (d. 1862) [1]

Honoré de Balzac, French novelist (La Comédie Humaine), born in Tours, Indre-et-Loire, France (d. 1850)

John Stuart Mill

English philosopher, political economist and utilitarian, born in London

Gustav Mankell, Moravian-Swedish organist and composer, born in Christiansfeld, Denmark (d. 1880)

William Fargo, American expressman (founder of Wells Fargo and American Express Co), born in Pompey, New York (d. 1881)

Emile Erckmann [co-wrote with Alexandre Chatrian using penname Erckmann-Chatrian], French writer (Waterloo), born in Meurthe, France (d. 1899)

1822 Frédéric Passy, French economist and pacifist (Nobel Peace Prize 1901 for European Peace Movement), born in Paris, France (d. 1912)

Antoinette Brown Blackwell, American minister (1st ordained US female minister), born in Henrietta, New York (d. 1921)

James William Reilly, American lawyer, politician, and Brigadier General (Union Army), born in Akron, Ohio (d. 1905)

Amalia of Saxen-Weimar-Eisenach, Dutch princess and wife of Prince Henry of the Netherlands, born in Walferdange, Luxembourg (d. 1872)

1830 Hector Malot, French writer (Without Family), born in La Bouille, France (d. 1907)

Jules Méline, French statesman (d. 1925)

Sara Louisa Oberholtz, American economist and social reformer (children's school savings banks), born in Uwchlan Township, Pennsylvania (d. 1930)

Pedro Miguel Marques y Garcia, Spanish violinist and composer, born in Palma, Majorca, Spain (d. 1918)

(Joseph) Eaton Faning, British organist and composer (The Vikings; Mock Turtles), born in Helston, Cornwall, England (d. 1927)

Emile Berliner, German inventor (flat phonograph record, founded Deutsche Grammophon), born in Hanover, Germany (d. 1929)

1851 Rose Hawthorne Lathrop, American nun and daughter of Nathaniel Hawthorne (founded Dominican Sisters of Hawthorne), born in Lenox, Massachusetss (d. 1926)

Henri-Edmond Cross [Delacroix], French painter (Fauvism), born in Douai, France (d. 1910)

Eduard Buchner, German chemist, Nobel laureate (d. 1917)

Joshua Pim, Irish tennis player (Wimbledon 1893-94), born in Bray, Wicklow (d. 1942)

John Owen Jones, Welsh organist, violist, and composer, born at Bryncoed, Caernarfonshire, Wales (d. 1962)

Karel Komzák III, Austrian conductor and composer, born in Vienna, Austria (d. 1924) [1]

Władysław Sikorski, Polish World War II general and Prime Minister of Poland in exile (1939-43), born in Tuszów Narodowy, Austria-Hungary (d. 1943)

Sigrid Undset, Danish-born Norwegian writer (Kristin Lavransdatter, Nobel Prize for Literature 1928), born in Kalundborg, Denmark (d. 1949)

Faisal I of Iraq, King of the Arab Kingdom of Syria (1920–1933) & King of Iraq (1921–1933), born in Mecca, Saudi Arabia (d. 1933)

1883 Paul Arntzenius, Dutch painter, graphic artist and etcher, born in The Hague, Netherlands (d. 1965)

Faisal I, Arab statesman, King of Syria (1920) and King of Iraq (1921-33), born in Mecca, Ottoman Empire (d. 1933)

Felix Arndt, American organist, pianist, arranger, and composer ("Desecration Rag"; "Nola"), born in New York City (d. 1918) [1]

1889 William Lawther, English union leader (National Union of Mine Workers 1939-54), born in Choppington, England (d. 1976)

Beniamino Gigli, Italian lyric tenor (La Gioconde - "Enzo"; Metropolitan Opera, 1920-32), born in Recanati, Marche, Italy (d. 1957)

Adela Rogers St John "The World's Greatest Girl Reporter", American journalist, screenwriter and author (Foreign Correspondent), born in Los Angeles, California (d. 1988)

1894 Chandrashekarendra Saraswati, Indian Hindu sage, Jivanmukta (d. 1994)

R. J. [Reginald Joseph] Mitchell, English airplane designer (Supermarine Spitfire), born in Butt Lane, England (d. 1937)

Diego Abad de Santillán, Spanish anarchist (d. 1983)

Alexander Deyneka, Ukrainian painter (d. 1969)

1899 Estelle Taylor, American actress (The Ten Commandments), born in Wilmington, Delaware (d. 1958)

1899 John Marshall Harlan II, American lawyer, jurist and 91st Supreme Court Justice (1955-71), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1971)

1899 Lydia Cabrera, Cuban anthropologist and ethnographer of Cuban folklore and Afro-Cuban culture, born in Havana, Cuba (d. 1991) [1]

Max Euwe, Dutch World Chess Champion (1935-37), born in The Netherlands (d. 1981)

1901 Otto Waldis, Austrian actor (Port of Hell, Unknown World), born in Vienna, Austria-Hungary (d. 1974)

Hans Sahl, German American anti-Nazi Jewish writer, born in Dresden, Germany (d. 1993)

Jerzy Fitelberg, Polish composer, born in Warsaw, Russian Empire (d. 1951)

Margery Allingham, English detective writer (one of 'four 'Queens of Crime'), born in London, England (d. 1966)

1904 Russell Hardie, American actor (Sequoia, In Old Kentucky), born in Buffalo, New York (d. 1973)

Alan Rawsthorne, British classical and film score composer (Elegy for Guitar; The Cruel Sea), born in Deardengate House, Lancashire, England (d. 1971)

1905 Gerrit Achterberg, Dutch poet (Sailing), born in Nederlangbroek, Netherlands (d. 1962)

1905 Harry Campion, English statistician (1st Director of British Central Statistical Office), born in Worsley, England (d. 1996)

1905 John Emery, American actor (Ship Ahoy, Kronos), born in New York City (d. 1964)

Giuseppe Siri, Italian Catholic cardinal (d. 1989)

Carl Mydans, American photojournalist (Life Magazine, 1936-72), born in Medford, Massachusetts (d. 2004) [1]

James Stewart

American actor (The Philadelphia Story; It's a Wonderful Life; Mr Smith Goes to Washington; Vertigo), born in Indiana, Pennsylvania

Annie M. G. Schmidt, Dutch writer (Fam Doorsnee, Jip & Janneke), born in Kapelle, Netherlands (d. 1995)

Joseph Proce, American murder victim (3rd person attacked by NYC's Zodiac killer), (d. 1990)

Henry Cadbury Brown, English architect (Royal College of Art), born in Sarratt, England (d. 2009)

Bill Hewlett

American engineer and businessman (co-founder Hewlett-Packard), born in Ann Arbor, Michigan

Corneliu Coposu, Romanian politician (Christian Democratic National Peasants' Party), born in Bobota, Austro-Hungarian Empire (d. 1995)

1914 Hideko Maehata, Japanese swimmer (d. 1995)

Moshe Dayan

Israeli military leader and politician (Minister of Defense 1967-74), born in Degania Alef, Ottoman Empire

Peter Copley, British actor (Victim, Kingdom of Heaven, King & Country), born in Bushey, Hertfordshire, England (d. 2008)

Alexei Petrovich Maresiev, Russian flying ace (d. 2001)

1916 John McIntyre, Scottish theologian (Chaplin to the Queen in Scotland), born in Glasgow, Scotland (d. 2005)

1916 Owen Chadwick, English historian, priest and university chancellor, born in London, England (d. 2015)

1916 Trebisonda Valla, Italian athlete (d. 2006)

Bergur Sigurbjörnsson, Icelandic politician (d. 2005)

1917 Francis-Paul Demillac [Enyss Djemil], French violinist, composer, and pedagogue, born in Paris, France (d. 2014)

1917 Guy Favreau, French Canadian lawyer, politician and judge, born in Montréal, Quebec (d. 1967)

1917 Richard Cobb, British historian, born in Frinton-on-Sea (d. 1996)

George Gobel, American humorist, comedian and TV host (The George Gobel Show), born in Chicago, Illinois (d. 1991)

Elizabeth "Betty" Driver, British singer and actress (Coronation Street, Pardon the Expression), born in Leicester, England (d. 2011)

1920 John Cruickshank, Scottish WWII war hero (Victoria Cross) and banker, born in Aberdeen, Scotland

1920 William Simpson, Scottish trade union leader (d. 2001)

Hal Newhouser, American Baseball HOF pitcher (7 × MLB All-Star; World Series 1945; AL MVP 1944, 45; Triple Crown 1945; Detroit Tigers), born in Detroit, Michigan (d. 1998)

1921 John Harrison, British vice admiral and surgeon (Medical Director Royal Navy during Falklands War), born in Simla, British India (d. 2010)

1921 John Marchi, US Senator (Rep-R-NY 1957-2006), born in Staten Island, New York (d. 2009)

1921 Wolfgang Borchert, German writer, born in Hamburg (d. 1947)

Edith Fellows, American actress (Pennies From Heaven, She Married Her Boss), born in Boston, Massachusetts (d. 2011)

1925 D. French Slaughter Jr, American politician (Rep-R-VA, 1985-91), born in Culpeper, Virginia (d. 1998)

Bob Sweikert, American race car driver (d. 1956)

1926 George Hurst, British conductor (BBC Northern Orchestra. 1958-68; Bournemouth Sinfonietta. 1968-74), and educator, born in Edinburgh, Scotland (d. 2012)

1926 John Lucarotti, British-Canadian screenwriter (The Avengers; The Troubleshooters; Doctor Who), born in Aldershot, England (d. 1994)

1926 Vic Ames, American pop singer (Ames Brothers), born in Malden, Massachusetts (d. 1978)

David Barlow, British composer and pedagogue, born in Rothwell, England (d. 1977)

1927 David Hedison, American actor (Voyage to Bottom of Sea; Live and Let Die; The Colbys), born in Providence, Rhode Island (d. 2019)

1927 Franciszek Macharski, Polish Cardinal, Archbishop of Kraków (1978-2005), born in Kraków (d. 2016)

1927 Harry "Bud" Grant, American Pro Football HOF coach (NFL Coach of the Year 1969 Minnesota Vikings; 4 x Grey Cup C'ship Winnipeg Blue Bombers) and basketball forward (NBA C'ship 1950 Minnesota Lakers), born in Superior, Wisconsin (d. 2023) [1]

1927 Walter Aschaffenburg, German-American composer, born in Essen, Germany (d. 2005)

Al Aronowitz, American music journalist (New York Post; Saturday Evening Post), introduced The Beatles to Bob Dylan, born in Bordentown, New Jersey (d. 2005)

1928 David Berriman, CEO (Rose Thomson Young group of Lloyds Trustees)

André Carolus Cirino, Surinamese indigenous writer, born in Goede Hoop, Saramacca, Dutch Guiana (d. 2023)

James McEachin, American actor and author (Perry Mason, Harry-Tenafly), born in Rennert, North Carolina

1930 Robert Bunyard, Commandant (British Police Staff College)

Chiharu Igaya, Japan, slalom (Olympic silver 1956)

1931 Ken Boyer, American baseball player (d. 1982)

1931 Louis Smith, American jazz trumpeter, composer, band leader, and educator, born in Memphis, Tennessee (d. 2016)

Constance Towers, American stage and screen actress (Capitol; Shock Corridor; Naked Kiss; General Hospital), born in Whitefish, Montana

José Mujica

40th President of Uruguay (2010-2015), champion of the poor and former urban guerrilla with the Tupamaros, born in Montevideo, Uruguay

Anthony Zerbe, Cal, actor (Harry-O, Centennial, They Call Me Mr Tibbs)

1936 Mister Satan [Sterling Magee], American blues guitarist, singer, and percussionist (Satan & Adam), born in Mount Olive, Mississippi (d. 2020) [1]

Dave Hill, American golfer (Vardon Trophy 1969; US Open 1970 runner-up; 13 x PGA Tour titles), born in Jackson, Michigan (d. 2011)

Alan Smithers, British professor

1938 Astrid Kirchherr, German photographer, helped establish The Beatles image, born in Hamburg, Germany (d. 2020)

María Luisa Ozaita, Spanish pianist, harpsichordist, musicologist, conductor, and composer (Pelleas y Melisanda), born in Baracaldo, Spain (d. 2017)

(Frederick) "Shorty" Long, American soul singer, and pianist ("Devil with the Blue Dress On"; "Here Comes The Judge"), born in Birmingham, Alabama (d. 1969)

1940 Sadaharu Oh, of Yomiuri Giants (Japan), hit 868 career HR

Stan Mikita

Canadian Hockey Hall of Fame center (Stanley Cup 1961; Hart Memorial Trophy [MVP] 1967, 68; 6 x NHL First All-Star Team), born in Sokolče, Slovak Republic

Goh Chok Sole, premier of Singapore (1990- )

1941 John Strasberg, American actor

Carlos Hathcock, American Marine Corps sniper with a service record of 93 confirmed kills (Vietnam War), born in Little Rock, Arkansas (d. 1999)

1942 Lynn Davies, Welsh athlete (Olympic gold long jump 1964), born in Nantymoel, Wales

1942 Paula [Jill Jackson], American pop singer ("Hey Paula"), born in McCamey, Texas

1943 Iain Vallance [Baron Vallance of Tummel], CEO (British Telecom)

1943 Martin Honeysett, British cartoonist (Punch, Private Eye), born in Hereford (d. 2015)

English rock vocalist ("With A Little Help From My Friends"; "Cry Me A River"; "You Are So Beautiful"), born in Sheffield, England

Boudewijn de Groot, Dutch folk singer ("Sleep Well, Mr. President"), born in a Japanese concentration camp, near Batavia, occupied Dutch East Indies (now Jakarta, Indonesia)

Austrian businessman (founder, owner Red Bull Racing; FC Red Bull Salzburg, RB Leipzig; co-creator Red Bull energy drink), born in Sankt Marein im Mürztal, Austria

1945 Lord Hollick, CEO (MAI)
